reporter_caption.center: SCOTT v. AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY, 164 Ohio St. 528 (1956)

caption.center: SCOTT ET AL., APPELLANTS v. THE FAYETTE COUNTY AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY,

syllabus.italic: Supreme Court — Dismissal — No debatable constitutional question
involved — Appropriation of property by county agricultural
society — Appropriation for use as fairgrounds — Property
leased by county commissioners — Sublet to agricultural society
— Procedural requirements — Necessity of availability of funds
for payment of compensation — Section 719.21, Revised Code —
Necessity for appropriation — Public use — What constitutes —
Appropriation of land for parking-lot purposes — Alleged excess
condemnation — Remedy of landowner — Injunction — Statutory
— Section 19, Article I, Constitution — Due process — Article
XIV, Amendments, U.S. Constitution — Implied reservation of
powers of individual rights — Article IX, Amendments,

opinion.posture: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Fayette County.
opinion.attorneys:
Mr. Robert N. Gorman and Mr. Carrington T. Marshall, for appellants.
Messrs. Brownfield Malone, for appellee.
opinion.opinion_text:
It is ordered and adjudged that this appeal as of right be, and the same hereby is, dismissed for the reason that no debatable constitutional question is involved.
Appeal dismissed.
WEYGANDT, C.J., MATTHIAS, HART and ZIMMERMAN, JJ., concur.
BELL, J., not participating.Page 529
